awd_titl_txt: Defining and Modeling the Response of a Low Gradient Coastal System to Rapid Sea-Level Rise during the Late Pleistocene
awd_abstract_narration:
Rates of sea-level rise have accelerated over the last 120 years, from global rates of approximately zero in the 19th century, to an average rate in the 20th century of approximately 1.7 mm/y, to the present rate of 3.4 +/- 0.4 mm/y. Geologic observations of sea-level high-stand markers from 130,000 to 80,000 years ago suggest that global sea level attained a height of approximately +2 m (relative to modern sea level) for several millennia, possibly followed by a rapid rise to approximately +6 m. The goal of this proposal is to determine how the coasts of North Carolina and Virginia responded to sea level changes during these times. This project will collect geophysical data and sediment cores in the North Carolina and Virginia region. The deposits contain a record of past changes due to erosion and sedimentation that occurred during rapid sea level rise that could provide an analog for future conditions in this region.  The project provides training for graduate and undergraduate students. 

This proposal will address the objective of understanding the geological and morphodynamic response of a low-gradient coastal system to sea-level rise. In eastern North Carolina and Virginia, late Pleistocene transgressive to high-stand deposits occur seaward of the Marine Isotope Stage 5 paleoshoreline on the coastal plain and beneath the modern estuaries. Geophysical data and sediment cores will be collected in two study areas in the region. These data will be used in the future to develop a 3D model of facies relationships and the sequence stratigraphic framework of the region, to develop numerical hydrodynamic models to understand the response of the coastal system to rapid sea level rise, and to place vertical constraints on Pleistocene sea levels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project improved the understanding of coastal evolution in northeastern North Carolina during past periods of rapid sea-level rise.  Knowledge gained includes an improved understanding of changes to the environments (salinity, sediments) and processes (tidal, wave energy, etc.) as sea level rose and the shoreline moved westward during the last interglacial episode, between approximately 125,000 and 80,000 years ago, and again at approximately 47,000 years ago.  Fossils, sediments, and elemental data extracted from cores (Figs. 1 and 2) allowed us to identify different environments (e.g., estuary, shelf, beach, tidal flat, etc.) which were dated using primarily Optically Stimulated Luminescence (OSL).  Environments were mapped using the core data (Fig. 3) as well as seismic and ground penetrating radar data.  The regional climate conditions were examined using pollen.  It was found that the ancient ocean shoreline was positioned up to 120 km (75 miles) landward of the present ocean shoreline, and coastal and shelf conditions included lower salinity nearshore, greater tidal range, and less wave energy than today (Fig. 2).  The data suggest a decrease in salinity from south to north, possibly related to flow from the Roanoke River.  The coastal/shelf region exhibited rapid flooding, initially producing normal marine salinity conditions, and then shoaling of the bottom as sediments were deposited on the inner shelf likely resulting from low wave energy and enhanced tides.  Shelf deposits transition upward to tidal estuary deposits suggesting the occurrence of barrier islands and an enhanced tidal range.   

This knowledge will aid in a more accurate assessment of future changes to the coast as sea level continues to rise.  Data are being used to produce computer models of the changes to tides, waves and currents that occurred during flooding of this region.  By extension, some of this knowledge will be beneficial to understanding the evolution of other coastal regions as sea level continues to rise.  The ability to forecast changes provides a means of managing coastal resources in the future.  Additionally, the improved understanding of the shallow geology of this region will allow better models of ground-water flow changes in response to sea-level rise and storm impacts.
